title: Elmyra Duff
subtitle: A metaphor for certainty.
content: From this perspective, humanity shares a striking resemblance with Elmyra Duff. Elmyra is a cartoon character from the Warner Bros. television series Tiny Toon Adventures. She is a cute, redheaded girl who lives in a nice, suburban home and attends Acme Looniversity. She serves as the school nurse and loves animals above all. In her pleated skirt, white socks, and black shoes, she stalks the neighborhood looking for animals. When she encounters one, she picks it up and expresses her love by hugging it. Tight. Tighter. And tighter. Until life starts to drain out of the creature. Of course, this is not love. It is an obsession coupled with a pathological disregard for life. This is reflected in the many abandoned pet toys, doghouses, and kitty baskets strewn across Elmyra’s ghostly back yard. Elmyra wears a light blue bow in her hair. If you look close, you see that it is held together in the middle by a gerbil’s skull. I am haunted by the image of humanity as Elmyra. So obsessed with certainty, that we drain life from all that which we encounter. I am terrified by our craving for control and prediction, profit and growth. Our back yard strewn with decaying toys and abandoned houses. I am horrified by the ceremonial headgear we wear in this ritual of destruction. A crown adorned with the symbol of our lasting legacy on this planet: the skull.

title: Myth
subtitle: Who am I? And why am I here?
content:
According to Joseph Campbell, we have always answered metaphysical questions through myths.[1] However, these myths have undergone dramatic changes. Starting in the upper Palaeolithic, hunter gatherer societies lived according to the way of the animal powers. All of nature was infused with divine presence and shamans mediated between spirits and humans, defending life, health, and fertility against death, diseases, and disaster. Each culture's main hunting animal took the center stage in this ritual of sacrifice and renewal. Man and animal partook as equals in an eternal dance of divine life.[2]

Then, in around 10,000 BCE, the end of the last ice-age ushered in the agricultural age. The soil became the center of our universe. Mother Earth with life-giving powers. The annual cycle of planting, growing, and harvesting of crops according to the seasons took center stage in a repetitive rhythm of life and death. A Great Goddess was both creator and destroyer of life, usually paired with a son or consort. An every-dying, ever-resurrecting lesser male God. For millennia, we lived according to the way of the seeded earth.

Around 3,000 BCE, the first high civilizations in China, India, and Mesopotamia changed all that. They turned their gaze away from the soil, and toward the sky. As they learned to interpret the night sky to predict the seasons, they founded the way of the celestial lights. In this mythology, a sun king with a radiant crown became the center of the cosmos. His court, the orbiting planets in the clockwork universe of an eternal cosmic play.[3]

This mythology has undergone many iterations. Many a warrior god has come and gone, smiting us with thunder, flood and pestilence. Yet, we are still infused with all above mythological systems. Today, many still appeal to spirits and divinities for fertility or success. Legions partake in rituals re-enacting the death and resurrection of a male god. Countless others live in societies controlled by sun kings in all but name, orchestrating masses with clockwork precision while crushing the formidable power of an age old rival - female fertility.[4]

These myths are still very much with us today. And to all you hard-nosed empiricists shrugging your shoulders right now, ask yourselves this: what are you really doing when you read bedtime stories of fairy-magic to your children? When you put up a Christmas tree, or display your status through a three-pointed star on the hood of your car? What are you re-enacting when you surrender most of your waking life to the god of productivity, or idolize a radiant prophet of wealth and success with ten million followers on Instagram? In all these cases, you are partaking in an age-old mythological narrative. A narrative established in response to the deepest kind of uncertainty. You are enacting a play, formulated to answer a metaphysical question: Who am I? And why am I here?

[1] Campbell, Joesph. The Power of Myth [2] Campbell, Joseph. Historical Atlas of World Mythology. Vol. 1: The Way of the Animal Powers [3] Campbell, Joesph. The Hero with a Thousand Faces [4] Eliade, Mircea. Shamanism, Archaic Techniques of Ecstasy.

title: Practical Certainty
subtitle: On the triangle of belief, trust, and choice.
content:
We can think of uncertainty as one of two polar opposites. After all, un-certain is simply the negation of certain, right? If we know what certainty is, then uncertainty is simply the opposite. This simple argument is appealing, but it rests on the assumption that we know what certainty is. But do we? As we have seen in the page on ignorance, the last centuries have been marked by a tremendous loss of certainty in the sciences. An explosion of ignorance of sorts. Even the "hard" sciences of physics and mathematics have jettisoned the idea of absolute certainty. We have proof that if a sub-atomic particle's position is known, then its momentum must be uncertain (Schrödinger). If a formal whole-number system is consistent, then it must be incomplete (Gödel). This begs an important question: If there is no such thing as certainty, then what could be its opposite?

You might argue that this question is sterile and academic. Mere echoes bouncing off wood-paneled walls in the seminar. You might argue that in daily life, we do not rely on absolute certainty. All we need is practical certainty, the ability to satisfice[1] based on the best available knowledge at a given time. In the absence of absolute certainty, we turn to the next best thing: Credence: A belief sufficiently trusted to form the basis of our life's choices. But this should give us pause. Credence, or practical certainty, is based on three fundamental concepts: belief, trust, and choice. This highlights the point that our actions are based not on certain knowledge, but on firmly held beliefs. Of the many beliefs we may hold, only a few are held with enough conviction to support our choices. These are the beliefs we endow with a magical property: trust.

==add paragraph on justified true belief==

This reveals that certainty is not a mechanical property of knowledge at all. It is something altogether more ghostly and esoteric. Certainty is the faith we place in our beliefs. An intangible affect we depend on for all our decision making. From this perspective, the nature of uncertainty comes into sharper view. Uncertainty is that which corrupts, corrodes, and consumes this faith. That which wears away the trust we grant our beliefs. It is a force that dissolves the habitual, reflexive mechanism of our decision-making. It is the destroyer of credence… and the creator of possibility.

[1] Satisficing - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satisficing

title: Probability
subtitle: The limits of stochastic inference.
content:
“Probability is the most important concept in modern science, especially as nobody has the slightest notion what it means.” - Bertrand Russel [1]

The concept of probability is under-appreciated by most and truly understood by few. Probability theory is so crucial that in terms of importance, it rivals Einstein’s General Relativity and Newton’s Law of Motion.[2] As the basis for quantitative analysis of experimental data, it underpins modern empirical science as a whole. Especially in the field of computer science, probabilistic methods underlie a host of important functions. Machine learning, signal processing, image-, speech-, and text-recognition, as well as data compression all heavily rely on algorithms using statistical inference. That means that every time your mobile phone pings a cell tower, you make a purchase online, type a word into a search engine, or walk past a surveillance camera, your actions are analyzed by probabilistic means.

Probability theory has found practical application in so many domains, that it is increasingly employed to make decisions in situations of uncertainty. This has led to the words probability and uncertainty to be used interchangeably, and to the false notion that uncertainty itself is a metric that can be captured, quantified, and resolved. This understanding is flawed, or at least only applies within a limited domain.

In probability science, uncertainty is represented through probability distributions. A probability distribution is a function that assigns probabilities to all possible outcomes of an event, where the sum of all probabilities is equal to one. However, this requires some prior knowledge. To represent uncertainty using a normal distribution, one must know the mean, which is the average or central value of the distribution, and the standard deviation, which represents the spread or variability of the distribution. For a binomial distribution, one must know the number of trials (n) and the probability of success (p). For a Poisson distribution, only knowledge of the average rate of occurrence (λ) is needed. An exponential distribution, related to the Poisson, requires knowledge of rate parameter (λ). Bayesian statistical methods require the knowledge of not one, but two probability distributions (prior distribution and likelihood function) that are updated into a posterior function based on available evidence.

Without getting too technical here, I think you can see my point. In order to represent uncertainty using probabilistic methods, we already need to know a great deal about what is going on. But this poses a dilemma. Uncertainty is about the unknown, yet these methods require considerable prior knowledge to have predictive power. How can we use probabilistic methods in situations of radical uncertainty, when this knowledge is not available? The answer is we cannot. Probabilistic methods only apply when partial knowledge is available. To be fair, this is indeed frequently the case. We can apply stochastic inference when the probability distribution is known, or when ample historical data such as actuary tables or time series data is available. When enough data is available, it is also possible to use non-parametric [3] methods, a class of statistical techniques that do not require assumptions about the probability distribution of the data being analyzed. These methods can be useful when the data does not follow a specific probability distribution. However, they also require a critical mass of prior knowledge and still make some assumptions about the data, such as independence, stationarity, and the bandwidth or kernel function used in estimation.

But when so much is already known, are we still dealing with uncertainty? Arguably yes, but it is the resolvable kind. The lowercase 'u' uncertainty that can be overcome by applying existing models and available data. However, we must guard against using these models when distributions are unknown. Especially in high-stakes environments like environmental models, energy grid management, or modeling of financial markets, probabilistic models have diminished predictive power. In part, this is due to their non-stationary nature. In mathematics, the term "non-stationary" typically refers to a process that changes over time. More specifically, one in which the statistical properties of the process, such as the mean or variance, change over time. Although there are probabilistic methods to capture non-stationary processes [4], these have little predictive power when dealing with complex dynamical systems. These are systems with a large number of interacting components that exhibit complex and often unpredictable behavior that arises from the interactions between components. Complex dynamical systems are ubiquitous in nature and can be found in a wide range of fields, including physics, chemistry, biology, economics, and sociology.

We will explore complex dynamical systems in depth in the branch on [knowledge], but for now we can summarize this page thus: all probabilistic methods of quantifying uncertainty require prior knowledge to have predictive power. This limits their domain of application to the situations where this knowledge is available. In situations of radical uncertainty, or when complex dynamical systems are involved. Probabilistic representations of uncertainty have little validity.

Probability is not uncertainty.

[1] Bertrand Russell, 1929 Lecture (cited in Bell 1945, 587.)

[2] Lindley, D. (2013). Understanding Uncertainty (Revised ed.). Wiley.

[3] Non-parametric methods: histograms, kernel density estimation, empirical distribution function, quantile-quantile plots. These methods have the advantage that they do not presuppose knowledge about probability distributions. However, they require large sample sizes to make meaningful statements.

[4] Non-stationary processes can be modeled by autoregressive integrated moving average (ARIMA) or stochastic differential equations (SDEs). These methods require even more knowledge of the process being modeled, such as the autocorrelation, probability distributions, and the appropriate differential equations.

title: Semantic Mirror
subtitle: A figure-ground reversal of perception.
content:
So here is the claim I will develop throughout the book: Uncertainty is what philosophers might call an ontological primitive - a fundamental building block of reality. As I have mentioned earlier, I submit that uncertainty is the relationship with a negative space. Because this statement by itself raises more questions than it answers, I promise to spend the rest of this book clarifying them as best I can. However, for now please note that, if true, it has some astonishing consequences. This interaction with a negative space creates a semantic mirror effect of sorts. A figure-ground reversal that makes us see uncertainty as the opposite of what it really is. For example, we commonly think of uncertainty as the unknown, but instead, I submit that it is the force that shapes our body of knowledge. We perceive uncertainty as a threat to our unfolding potential, but I prefer to think of it as that which enables our agency. We think of uncertainty as an obstacle to innovation, but it is the ultimate generator of creativity. Lastly, we often perceive it as a corrosive force, but I argue that it provides the connectivity that gives us meaning.

With this framework in mind, and having disentangled the most common misperceptions about uncertainty in this branch, we are ready to jump into the next branch and explore the above mentioned domains in some depth. [knowledge], [agency], [creativity], and [meaning].

title: Risk
subtitle: Resolvable versus radical uncertainty.
content:
At this point, you might retort that, philosophy and linguistics aside, there are entire branches of science examining uncertainty with objective, empirical methods. You might argue that uncertainty is a quantifiable metric that can be represented through probabilistic means. And you would be correct. In probability science, uncertainty is represented through probability distributions, which provide a way to quantify and model the likelihood of different outcomes. The fields of thermodynamics, quantum physics, information theory, and artificial intelligence would be unthinkable without the use of probabilistic methods. Applied probability theory has shown to have great predictive power and underlies many advanced technologies we take for granted. Surely, these stochastic models can quantify and represent uncertainty, right?

Although it is useful to associate the concepts of uncertainty and probability, we should not confuse the two, for they are two distinct ideas. I will use an example from the field of economics to illustrate this. According to modern economic theory, rational agents make decisions based on projections of anticipated value. This value can be captured by a utility function that represents an agent's preferences among a set of choices. This is usually calculated by multiplying the weighted sum of utility values with their respective probabilities. This method makes a host of assumptions. For one, it assumes that the agent making the decision is rational - a claim challenged by any number of passing observations of human behavior. It also assumes that agents accurately map their values, available choices, and expectations of future reward - an idea increasingly challenged by cognitive science. Most importantly, the method also assumes the knowledge of probabilities for each possible outcome. This last assumption highlights an intrinsic limitation of the principle underlying all of probability: It is a method that substitutes the lack of specific knowledge of an instance with general knowledge of the whole.

Probabilistic methods infer information about each instance through knowledge about the stochastic distribution of the whole set. That is tremendously useful, but this tool is limited to the domains in which these stochastic distributions are known. Unsurprisingly, this is not always the case. Oftentimes, when building predictive models, the creators simply assume a distribution such as the normal or log-normal distribution. However, this small shortcut conceals a critical failure. It is the failure to make a distinction that used to be well known in economics. Towering figures such as John Maynard Keynes and Frank Knight used to make a distinction between uncertainty and risk. Economists Mervyn King and John Kay clearly point out this distinction:

“We have chosen to replace the distinction between risk and uncertainty deployed by Knight and Keynes with a distinction between resolvable and radical uncertainty. Resolvable uncertainty is uncertainty which can be removed by looking something up (I am uncertain which city is the capital of Pennsylvania) or which can be represented by a known probability distribution of outcomes (the spin of a roulette wheel). With radical uncertainty, however, there is no similar means of resolving the uncertainty – we simply do not know. (…) Radical uncertainty cannot be described in the probabilistic terms applicable to a game of chance. It is not just that we do not know what will happen. We often do not even know the kinds of things that might happen.”[1]

Risk is resolvable uncertainty that can be eliminated using prior knowledge, such as probability distributions, time series data, actuary tables, or algorithms capturing human behavioral patterns. This method is useful, but like all tools it has limited domain validity. Representing uncertainty probabilistically is useful when there is enough prior knowledge about the process being modeled. Radical uncertainty cannot be captured that way, because it deals with the unknown unknown. Intellectual honesty demands that we acknowledge these limitations and abstain from cloaking radical uncertainty in probabilities.

Risk is not uncertainty.

[1] King, Mervyn A, and J A Kay. Radical Uncertainty : Decision-Making for an Unknowable Future. London, The Bridge Street Press, 2020.

title: Spacetime
subtitle: The past and the present.
content:
With the possible exception of deductive inference (pure logic), our choices interact with the dimension of time. Observations of the past are used to choose actions in the present in order to affect a favorable future. This dynamic dalliance with time is another primary root of uncertainty. Our knowledge of the past is dubious, our choices in the present are fickle, and our predictions of the future are unreliable at best. This entanglement with time is important because it affects our beliefs about the past, our actions in the present, and our expectations about the future. All of these are imperfect, dynamic, volatile, and ever uncertain. As they should be. In this section, we will explore the entanglement of uncertainty with time and space.

title: Evolution
subtitle: Evolution as embedding of knowledge about the environment.
content:
Uncertainty has an evolutionary root. That is because all life partakes in a continuous dance. A feedback loop between organism and environment. Through recursive interaction, life and its surroundings modify and encode each other. By encoding I mean organisms embodying features of their environment and the environment being shaped by features of organic life. On one side, the environment gradually forms the body shape, behavior, and sensory-motor patterns of the organism through evolution. On the other side, the feeding, breathing, excreting, reproduction, and niche-creation gradually forms the environment. The environment and the organism shape and encode each other in a continuous loop.

On the side of the organism, this process takes place through the 3-step mechanism of natural selection:

  1. diverging features in members of a population (mutation)
  2. differential rates of replication (reproductive advantage)
  3. diffusion of naturally selected features (heritability)

From this evolutionary perspective, each phenotype[1] represents embodied knowledge about its environment. Even the niches shaped by life in the environment could be said to represent a kind of knowledge. Knowledge about the inhabitants. Our common understanding that uncertainty is related to knowledge is, of course, correct. However, this connection goes far beyond the narrow definition of knowledge as propositions or facts held within the human mind. As we will see in the branch about [knowledge], the full scope of uncertainty can only be understood through the frame of embodied knowledge, defined as agents shaped by evolution to integrate information about their environment.

But before we delve into the domain of knowledge, we must acknowledge the role of evolution as a whole. Each living organism is an embodied bet on differential chances of survival. A bet on the optimal fitted-ness between it and the inhabited arena. For all life, this is a bet most uncertain.

[1] Phenotype: In genetics, the phenotype is the set of observable characteristics or traits of an organism. The term covers the organism's morphology (physical form and structure), its developmental processes, its biochemical and physiological properties, its behavior, and the products of behavior. This is distinct from the genotype, an organism's genetic material.

title: Metaphysics
subtitle: The uncertainty of high-level abstractions.
content:
Perhaps we became humans when we started burying our dead. Prehistorically, that was the moment when we first addressed our metaphysical uncertainty by asking these original questions: Who are we? Where do we come from? And where do we go? Finding answers to these questions is hard, but the attempt at doing so is part of our human heritage. Unfortunately, the confusion starts at the word metaphysics, and it goes back a long time. The term originally refers to a book by Aristotle who referred to it as πρώτη φιλοσοφία : first philosophy. A later scholar called Andronicus of Rhodes took it upon himself to creatively rename the book τὰ μετὰ τὰ φυσικὰ βιβλία : the books after physics, because he had placed it after the books on physics in his anthology. Unfortunately, this editorial mistake survived and was later taken too literally by medieval scholars. Thomas Aquinas thought metaphysics should only be taught to students after they had mastered physics, and others interpreted the title to mean beyond the physical realm. Centuries later, we are still saddled with these misunderstandings.

The word metaphysics carries otherworldly associations of mysticism, magic, and magnetism. Its mere mention makes some people reach for their pistol 🔫 . This sorry state of affairs is as unfortunate as it is groundless. Metaphysics is simply one of the four main branches of philosophy, along with epistemology, logic, and ethics. This branch studies the fundamental nature of reality. If this sounds a bit woo-hoo to you, then I would like to address it thus: If astronomy studies the properties of objects moving through space, then metaphysics explores what it means to be an object, what a property is, and why both exist in a topological entity called space. Nothing strange or otherworldly here. Just science.

And this is how the term metaphysics will be used going forward in this book. Not as a realm beyond the physical, but as practical inquiry into the first principles of reality. It is simply an exploration of the high-level abstractions we hold about the physical world around us as well as the inner world of symbolic constructs of our own cognition.

title: The Past
subtitle: Re-interpreting bygones.
content:
Some view the past as bathed in the golden glow of timeless glory. A time in which founders and heroes shaped our identity with prophetic hands. Others see the past as crude habitat of our primitive forebears. Savages living archaic lives that were nasty, brutish, and short. Both of these views are equally absurd, but perhaps not for the reasons most apparent to us. For one, they do not stand up to scrutiny by historians and archeologists. But also, these views make a false assumption that is all too common. They view the past as a settled historical fact. Something fixed and static. Frozen objects, gradually receding in the rearview mirror, driven by the unrelenting forward motion of time. But past events are not distant monoliths of questionable relevance. As we have seen in the previous section on [evolution], they are the raw material from which we manufacture a precious commodity: Prediction and choice.

The past is a malleable material because our choices are based on the beliefs we hold about it. Beliefs shaped from partial knowledge, cognitive biases, and arbitrary interpretations. Like looking at random blotches of ink on a paper, the image we perceive is not a historical fact. It is the Rorschach projection of ourselves onto a canvas. Our value system, identity, and decision-making are all based on these interpretations of the past. Interpretations fraught with uncertainty. If you have ever experienced or learned something new that utterly re-shaped your understanding of the past, then you know how acutely profound this feels in the present. It can be a simple aha-moment, or a life-changing realization affecting your sense of identity.

The past is not a monolithic mass, frozen in time. It is an endlessly changing space full of surprises, obscuring and revealing, pregnant with possibility. To master the art of uncertainty, we need to remain open to re-interpreting bygones, for they have not truly gone-by. Because our knowledge of the past is partial, every new thing we learn about it has the potential to change our present. Whether we like it or not, we participate in a fitful yet fertile dance with the dynamic past. For it holds the key to our future.

title: Relationship
subtitle: Our relationship with uncertainty over the ages.
content:
Our relationship with uncertainty has undergone significant changes through the ages. In prehistoric times, we developed a manipulative approach to uncertainty. Animism's invocation of spirits and ancestors was an attempt to influence uncertainty by pleading for otherworldly assistance. The goal was to alter uncertainty for the purpose of societal wellbeing. Fertility rituals and offerings soliciting a good harvest are remnants of this old tradition.

In the age of empires, state and religious authority perfected the practice of exploiting the relationship with uncertainty for the purpose of societal control. Authorities learned that the illusion of ordaining certainty was essential for their claim to legitimacy.

In the last few centuries, and certainly since the enlightenment, we began our attempt to eliminate uncertainty outright. A new period began in which the scientific pursuit of certain knowledge attempted to banish uncertainty from our lives. This reductionist approach ushered in a world view in which absolute knowledge is the goal state for which uncertainty has to be overcome.

Throughout humanity's stages of development, we have attempted to alter uncertainty through the use of magic, exploit it through the brute-force imposition of illusions, and exterminate it outright via reductionism. Perhaps humanity is finally mature enough to do what is hardest: to acknowledge the reality that uncertainty is always around, between, and within us. Irreducibly and permanently. It is a thread in the fabric of existence, woven into the reality of our lives. Instead of altering, exploiting, or eliminating it, we ought to participate in its power to create possibility. We must learn to domesticate and manage it, for it is the key to everything that lies in the future.

title: The Beast
subtitle: Something is missing.
content:
Thinking about uncertainty is hard, and as I found out, writing about it even harder. However, it is not immediately apparent why. "Uncertain" is a common word, indicating something only partially known or not entirely predictable. This may appear simple, but as you are about to find out, it is anything but. I have come to think of uncertainty as a profoundly misunderstood concept. At the core, this is due to its absential nature. I borrow this term from Terence Deacon, who used it to describe phenomena defined by their causal relationship with something missing or absent.[1]

I submit that uncertainty is far more significant than is commonly thought, but because of its absential nature, its true importance has mostly eluded us. Like "truth", "reality", and "information", uncertainty is an abstract concept that is intimately entwined with lived experience, yet it has not received the attention and scrutiny of the former. This book is an attempt to redress this asymmetry. It is the exploration of the nature of uncertainty in general, and its relevance in our knowledge, agency, creativity, and meaning-making in particular.

Don't be fooled by its hazy appearance. Uncertainty is a formidable beast!

[1] Deacon, T. W. (2011). Incomplete Nature: How Mind Emerged from Matter [Kindle Android version]. Retrieved from Amazon.com
